doc.title: SMC (6273.T): Conference Call Takeaway: Shift toward longer-term recovery starting to emerge; maintain BU
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS/SMC 6273.T Conference Call Takeaways Shift toward longer-term recovery starting to emerge maintain BuySMC 6273.T Confere_2025-08-28

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS

passages.text: On the morning of August 28, we hosted a conference call for domestic and international investors with SMC Corporation's Masahiro Ota, Director, Executive Officer, and General Manager of the Finance and Accounting Division.

1Q earnings marked a rough start toward achieving full- year guidance (LINK), but we were able to confirm through today's call that SMC is working to normalize inventory levels, and we believe earnings are close to bottoming out. We are upbeat about SMC taking active measures to address the factors behind the gap between its long- term targets and the current situation. Once demand and SMC's production/sales streamline, we expect to see a recovery in profitability and growth. We reiterate our Buy rating on SMC as a factory automation stock with inexpensive multiples and high growth potential. Below we summarize key points from the conference call.

1Q/3/26 sales/operating profits came to ¥200.1 bn/¥44.4 bn, representing progress of less than \(25\%\) toward full- year guidance of ¥850 bn/¥215 bn, for a sluggish start in 1Q. However, we have a positive view of the production/inventory adjustments that are now being made. An analysis of operating profit growth shows that although sales volume made a positive contribution, this was more than offset by negative contributions from forex fluctuations and lower production amid inventory adjustments. Usually, when SMC's top- line trends improve, production also improves, but in 1Q prioritizing inventory adjustments had the opposite effect on capacity utilization. SMC looks to be strengthening its inventory management, mainly for semiconductor- related customers, and we believe the effects of this are gradually emerging. Orders from electronics customers, mainly in semiconductors, are also showing signs of picking up in some regions, and we believe SMC's earnings are finally approaching a bottom.

SMC disclosed its latest estimates of the impact of US tariff policy. At the time of the FY3/25 full- year earnings announcement in May, SMC had estimated an impact of US \(4.5mn from 10\%\) reciprocal tariffs plus tariffs on steel and aluminum. SMC said it now expects the impact to be US \(64 mn from 15\%\) reciprocal tariffs on Japan
plus tariffs on steel, aluminum, and copper.

We believe SMC should be able to pass on these additional costs, given its top market share in the US pneumatics market. SMC said it intends to carefully consider the competitive environment when deciding how to pass on costs, as its estimated \(30\%\) market share in the US is not as dominant as its approximately \(65\%\) share in Japan. Although SMC's comments were somewhat cautious, reflecting weak capex sentiment in the US market, we believe it will ultimately be able to offset the impact of tariffs by passing on costs, given that it has successfully implemented price hikes in other regions.

SMC implemented a uniform \(10\%\) price hike in Japan in June. Although the impact varies from customer to customer, SMC said the price hikes have generally been well- received. We believe SMC's high domestic market share of around \(65\%\) has helped it to pass on price increases. The company also said customers are aware of the inflationary environment in Japan, which has compelled even SMC to diverge from its very disciplined price retention for pneumatic equipment to date and raise prices. SMC said that \(60 - 70\%\) of customers have already accepted the price hikes and that it could see a real price hike effect of just over \(5\%\) for its domestic business in FY3/26. SMC expects domestic sales of just over \(180bn\) in FY3/26, up \(10\%\) yoy, which means a \(5\%\) price hike effect could boost operating profits by almost \(10bn\) . SMC's initial guidance included a \(2bn\) positive impact on operating profits from price hikes globally. Although we need to monitor how price hikes are implemented, we believe this could offset the negative impact of production/inventory adjustments and the slow recovery in demand.

A key focus of the conference call was the US business outlook. SMC has strong expectations that manufacturing capex will pick up in the not too distant future following policy implementation by the current administration, including on tariffs. SMC management has expressed this upbeat expectation from the start of FY3/26, but inquiries from customers are sluggish overall at present.

That said, there are variations between sectors. In semiconductors/electronics, inquiries for chip- related products for memory investment by end- users have increased rapidly since July. In the auto sector, while inquiries related to traditional internal combustion engine vehicles are limited, SMC said it sees signs of recovery in other areas, such as development projects related to autonomous driving and commercial vehicles from EV makers.

In summary, SMC believes that although there is room to capture latent demand, many customers in the US are currently deciding to hold back on investment due to the uncertain macro environment. SMC noted that it expects capex sentiment to gradually recover now that uncertainties around tariffs are starting to drop off.
Semiconductors/Electronics: SMC sees some improvement in the US and Taiwan, and

expects earnings in China to be in line with or above guidance. Southeast Asia is behind the pace of its expectations, while Japan and Korea remain largely stagnant, in line with expectations. SMC said that it was a highlight, with good inquiries.

Automobiles: SMC said capacity sentiment was very strong at major EV makers in China in 1Q, and that inquiries were about from not only EV majors but also emerging EV makers from the same appliance/smartphone spaces. In other regions, the Japan market is quite and although there are still projects in the US pipeline, start dates have been postponed/frozen. Recovery does also not look imminent in other regions. SMC said it expects auto- related capex sentiment to recover once the impact of tariffs has played out and auto OEMs have a clearer view on the outlook for their supply chains.

SMC aware of stock valuation, capital policySMC is aware that the hurdles to achieving its long- term numerical targets, especially the ¥1 tn sales target for FY3/27, are getting higher. It also recognizes that investors are concerned about the company's large- scale capex amid sluggish earnings. SMC reiterated that these investments are necessary for future growth. It looks to be taking the necessary steps, such as optimizing production and inventory, to close the gap between its targets and current earnings. As part of this, SMC is paying attention to not only profitability but also declining capital efficiency and stock valuation. SMC said it intends to present an updated capital policy by the end of FY3/26 at the earliest, or by the end of FY3/27 (the final year of its long- term plan) at the latest. We take a positive view of this, as we think it is close to the direct message the stock market has been awaiting.
6273.T12m Price Target: ¥65,000Price: ¥45,360Upside: 43.3%
Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Research estimates, FactSet. Price as of 28 Aug 2025 close.

We, Yuichiro Isayama, Takeru Adachi and Takato Enoki, hereby certify that all of the views expressed in this report accurately reflect our personal views about the subject company or companies and its or their securities. We also certify that no part of our compensation was, is or will be, directly or indirectly, related to the specific recommendations or views expressed in this report.
Unless otherwise stated, the individuals listed on the cover page of this report are analysts in Goldman Sachs' Global Investment Research division.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Quantum is Goldman Sachs' proprietary database providing access to detailed financial statement histories, forecasts and ratios. It can be used for in- depth analysis of a single company, or to make comparisons between companies in different sectors and markets.

The rating(s) for SMC is/are relative to the other companies in its/their coverage universe: CKD Corp., Daifuku Co., Daikin Industries, Fanuc, Harmonic Drive Systems Inc., Hitachi Construction Machinery, Hoshizaki Corp., IHI, Japan Material, Kawasaki Heavy Industries, Keyence, Komatsu, Kubota, Kurita Water Industries, Makita, Misumi Group, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Nomura Micro Science, Okuma Corp., Omron Corp., Organo Corp., SMC, THK, Takeuchi MFG, Yaskawa Electric

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.

Not Rated (NR). Early- Stage Biotech (ES). An investment rating and a target price are not assigned pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when this company neither has a drug, treatment or medical device that has passed a Phase II clinical trial nor a license to distribute a post- Phase II drug, treatment or medical device. Rating Suspended (RS). Goldman Sachs Research has suspended the investment rating and price target for this stock, because there is not a sufficient fundamental basis for determining an investment rating or target price. The previous investment rating and target price, if any, are no longer in effect for this stock and should not be relied upon. Coverage Suspended (CS). Goldman Sachs has suspended coverage of this company. Not Covered (NC). Goldman Sachs does not cover this company.
